titleStmt.title: Monſieur Acarete du Biscay's Journey from Buenos Ayres to Peru

body.head: Monſieur Acarete du Biscay's Journey from Buenos Ayres to Peru

div.p:
I Left Buenos Ayres, and took the Road I
to Cordoua, leaving Santa Fe on my
right hand, of which place take this ac-
count, 'tis a Spaniſh Settlement dependant
upon Buenos Ayres, the Commander is
no more than a Lieutenant, and does no-
thing but by order from the Governor
of Buenos Ayres. 'Tis a little place con-
taining 25 Houfes, Houses without any Walls,
Fortifications, or Garriſon, diſtant 80
Leagues from Buenos Ayres Northward,
Situate upon the River de la Plata, large
Veſſels might come up to it, were it not
for a great bank that obstructs the pas-
sage a little above Buenos Ayres. Ne-
vertheleſs 'tis a very advantageous Poſt,
because 'tis the only passage from Peru,
Chili and Tucuman to Paraguay, and in a
manner the Magazine of the Commodi-

ties drawn from thence, particularly that
Herb already ſpoken spoken of, which they
cannot be without in thoſe Provinces.
The Soil is as good and Fertile here as
at Buenos Ayres ; and the Town having
nothing remarkably different from what
has been observ'd observed of Buenos Ayres, I
leave it, and proceed upon my Jour-
ney. 'Tis counted 140 Leagues from
Buenos Ayres to Cordoua, and becauſe because
ſome parts of the Road are uninhabited
for a long way together; I ſurnished my felf self at
my departure with what I
was inform'd I fhould should ftand stand in need
of; ſo I ſet out having a Savage for my
Guide, with Three Hofes Horses and Three
Mules, ſome to carry my Baggage, and
the reft rest to change upon the way when
that I rid upon was tired.
From Buenos Ayres, to the River Lu
can, and even as far as the River Recife,
30 Leagues, I pass’d by several Habita
tions and Farms cultivated by the Spani-
ards, but beyond Recife to the River
Salladillo, I faw saw none. Let it be obſer-
ved by the way, that theſe Rivers as well
as all the reſt in the Provinces of Buenos
Ayres, Paraguay and Tucuman, that fall
into the River de la Plata are fordable
on horfe horse -back; but when the Rains or
